subject: junit-quickcheck: seeking feedback
msgSnippet: Hi JUnit, I ve been working on junit-quickcheck (https://github.com/pholser/junit-quickcheck) on and off for a while now, and wanted to solicit some feedback
messageBody:
Hi JUnit,

I've been working on junit-quickcheck (https://github.com/pholser/junit-quickcheck) on and off for a while now, and wanted to solicit some feedback from potential users.

junit-quickcheck uses the ParameterSupplier extension point of JUnit's Theories runner to feed a number of randomly generated values to a @Theory method, as opposed to prescribing @DataPoint(s). As its name suggests, it draws inspiration from the Haskell QuickCheck library (http://www.cse.chalmers.se/~rjmh/QuickCheck/).

Though the project is built with Maven, none of the artifacts it produces are deployed to a central Maven repo (yet). Some of its dependencies are still snapshot versions: they can be found here:

-- https://github.com/pholser/junit.contrib

The 'theories' module of junit.contrib contains a version of the Theories runner that should be current with the JUnit 4.11 implementation, but:
1) better handles theory parameters involving generics
2) uses the Paranamer (http://paranamer.codehaus.org/) library to allow ParameterSignatures to carry a parameter's name
3) is packaged as org.junit.contrib.theories.*... rather than org.junit.experimental.theories.*...

This is the Theories runner that junit-quickcheck tests use. It in turn depends on:

-- https://github.com/pholser/paranamer

If you choose to build junit-quickcheck, you'll need to build these dependencies too.

I'm interested in any and all feedback, but am particularly interested in these items:

-- Would size control be useful (e.g. maxSize on @ForAll)? Maybe size() gets computed on every generation, as with Haskell QuickCheck?
-- Do we need different random distributions/@Frequency?
-- What other basic generator configs would be useful?
-- What other out-of-the-box generators would be useful?
-- Is the behavior of the out-of-the-box generators sufficient? What should be changed, if anything?
-- nextLong(min, max) and nextDouble(min, max) -- getting them to span the entire range.
-- Is @SuchThat with OGNL and Paranamer useful, or cute but not that helpful? What about without Paranamer?

Feel free to check this project out, and drop me an email or post issues to the project's GitHub site. Thanks for your time!

Regards,
Paul Holser
